pr_title: SQL/EQL: Add support for scalars within LIKE/RLIKE

timeline.message:
SQL/EQL: Add support for scalars within LIKE/RLIKE

- Add support for scalar functions on the field of SQL's LIKE/RLIKE
- Add support for scalar functions on the field of EQL's match
- Allow EQL's match to have the field argument as the last one

Closes: #55058

timeline.bodyText:
This should be an optimization rule not analysis (since the literal might not be folded).
It also seems incomplete - what if there are multiple non-literals? Is there any validation happening (verifier rule) in the chain?
timeline.author: costin

replies.bodyText:
I didn't like that either to take place in the analysis, but this way the Verifier will call the resolveType() on the Match which will indeed check that the patterns are constants (foldable).
If we apply the rule in the Optimizer that's after the verifier so it will "blow up".  Any suggestion?
replies.author: matriv

replies.bodyText:
It sounds to me like the resolveType method needs improving;
this rule moves the last items to the front of the list so instead of doing that outside Match, the class itself should have the proper behavior in place.

timeline.bodyText:
I would emphasize the two "versions" of match function, rather than mentioning that one argument needs to be a field.
Something more aligned with the (to be updated) documentation.
For example "either first or last argument of match must be a non-constant" (or around the same idea).
timeline.author: astefan

replies.bodyText: But now we allow the field to be anywhere, should we change and be stricter and allow only first and last?
replies.author: matriv
costin

replies.bodyText:
Yes, the rest must be literal strings. I believe we currently accept expressions that fold to strings as well.
I can update the documentation in a few places to reflect that. The rationale is that building regular expressions on the fly generally lead to poor performance or malformed expressions. For some of the existing EQL implementations, we need to know at compile time, so that the state machine can be built only once.
replies.author: rw-access

replies.bodyText:
The same restrictions apply to match, cidrMatch and wildcard.
At one point in the past, the function signature used to look like this: match(<regex>, <expr>), but that's been abandoned and now it's a variadic function of the form match(<expr>, <regex1>, <regex2>, ...). There may have been some tests that were of the old form that didn't get changed because they were being supported for backwards compatibility.  But I think it's okay to drop the ambiguous representation and stick with match(<expr>, <regex1>, <regex2>, ...)
